nodes.bodyText:
This statement still holds because they may have different scopes and optional flag.
DependencyNode(Artifact("com.google.guava:20.0"), scope:"provided") and DependencyNode(Artifact("com.google.guava:20.0"), scope:"compile") are different nodes.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -55,12 +54,10 @@ *
  • It does not contain optional dependencies of transitive dependencies. * * - *

    A full dependency graph is a dependency tree where each node's dependencies are resolved + *

    In a full dependency graph each node's dependencies are resolved * recursively. This graph has the following attributes: * *

      - *
    • The same artifact, which has the same group:artifact:version, appears in different nodes in - * the graph.

nodes.bodyText: I see the javadoc of buildFullDependencyGraph contains "including duplicates, conflicting versions".

nodes.bodyText: Use list. (without a list, the items of "the following attributes" are unclear)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -147,7 +123,11 @@ private DependencyNode resolveCompileTimeDependencies(
   /**
    * Finds the full compile time, transitive dependency graph including duplicates, conflicting
    * versions, and provided and optional dependencies. In the event of I/O errors, missing
-   * artifacts, and other problems, it can return an incomplete graph.
+   * artifacts, and other problems, it can return an incomplete graph. Each node's dependencies
+   * are resolved recursively. This graph has the following attributes:
+   * The scope of a dependency does not affect the scope of its children's dependencies.
+   * Provided and optional dependencies are not treated differently than any other
+   * dependency.

nodes.bodyText: I'm not sure I follow this. Do you want to duplicate the type in the @param for artifacts? JavaDoc fills that in automatically.

nodes.bodyText:
I meant the formatting around "the following attributes": * are resolved recursively. This graph has the following attributes: * *
    *
  • The scope of a dependency does not affect the scope of its children's dependencies. *
  • Provided and optional dependencies are not treated differently than any other dependency. *
